name: hard coal mine operation, underground | hard coal, run-of-mine | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/18331/documentation

This dataset represents the production of 1 kg run-of-mine (ROM) hard coal in South Africa extracted from underground mines. 125 million tonnes tones of ROM coal were produced from underground mines in 2014, accounting for 37% of South Africa's total ROM coal production. The two main forms of underground mining in South Africa are bord-and-pillar and longwall mining, with bord-and-pillar the predominant method due to the challenging geological conditions of most of South Africa's coal deposits. The dataset provides an average of both methods using a combination of industry data and government research reports for inputs to the mining process as well as methane emissions. Emissions to water should only be taken as indicative and are highly uncertain. Particulate emissions are rough estimates and not specific to South African mining. Land transformation assumes the mines are located in the grassland region of South Africa and that the pre-mining land use was livestock grazing. For land occupation, mine life is assumed to be 30 years (slightly below the average predicted lifetime of the mines in the industry data sample), with revegetation assumed to be completed within 10 years of mine closing (planning for closure is a legal requirement in South Africa, with revegetation usually commencing prior to the mine closing). Infrastructure requirements are generic, and are as applied in other ecoinvent coal mining datasets (in which total production over the life time of the mine is assumed to be 3*10^10 kg, an average value that is not representative for single mines or specific conditions). ;;[This dataset is meant to replace the following datasets:]

Underground coal extraction process starting from hard coal, in ground.

This activity ends with 1 kg hard coal (run-of-mine output) at the mine mouth. It does not include coal beneficiation. This dataset includes land use during operation, emissions into water and air, water extraction and use, energy requirements for operation and explosives. Post-closure rehabilitation of the mine is not included due to a lack of data on the requirements of revegetation.
category: B:Mining and quarrying/05:Mining of coal and lignite/051:Mining of hard coal/0510:Mining of hard coal

processDocumentation.timeDescription: 2014 is chosen as a base year because this is the latest year for which coal production and yield data were available (i.e. the most recent government statistics on coal mining). The industry data on which the dataset is based is somewhat earlier than 2014 (mid 2000 to 2010), but expert opinion consulted is that mining operations have not changed much over this time, thus it made sense to use the most recent production data. The water balance data used in the dataset is older (2001), and expert opinion is used to adjust for efficiency improvements, so that water consumption and emissions are more represenative of 2014.
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: Mining efficiency, energy and land requirements are specific to collieries mining the Witbank and Highveld coalseams in South Africa, whilst methane emissions and water use are estimated for underground mining in South Africa as a whole. Infrastructure requirements are not South African specific. Particulate emissions, radon emissions and certain emissions to water (ammonium, nickel, strontium and zinc), for which South African specific data was not available, are also not specific to South Africa.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: This dataset is representative of the two main forms of underground mining in South Africa, namely bord-and-pillar and longwall mining.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription:
Production volume and percentage of coal from underground mining is from annual government reporting (DMR, 2015). Energy and other material inputs are representative of three underground collieries in South Africa (industry data). Methane emissions and carbon dioxide emissions from low temperature oxidation are calculated using emission factors derived for South Africa's national GHG reporting (DEA, 2014) . Water quantities and sources are highly variable between mines, so representative water use values and sources are taken from a water balance project for South Africa (Pulles et al. 2001). Although relatively old (2001) this data source provided a more represenative sample of water use on South African mines with a sample of 41 mines (of which 16 are underground mines). Industry experts were consulted so as to adjust the water balance figures to account for the improvement in water efficiency in the intervening years, especially in coal washing, The water balance project highlighted poor water accounting on the mines, thus water emissions should only be taken as indicative and are highly uncertain. Land use for operational areas for infrastructure, extraction areas and dump areas are rough estimates. Infrastructure requirements are generic, and are as applied in other ecoinvent coal mining datasets (in which total production over the life time of the mine is assumed to be 3*10^10 kg, an average value that is not representative for single mines or specific conditions). References: Department of Minerals and Resources (2015) South Africa's Mineral Industry (SAMI) 2014/2015. Pretoria; DEA (2014) GHG NATIONAL INVENTORY REPORT SOUTH AFRICA 2000 -2010, November 2014. http://unfccc.int/resource/docs/natc/zafnir1.pdf (accessed September 2017);  Pulles, W., Boer, R. & Nel, S. 2001. A Generic Water Balance for the South African Coal Mining Industry. Water 
Research Commission Report No. 801/1/01.

exchanges.description: This dataset represents run-of-mine coal, which is assumed to equate to coal extracted, "coal, hard, unspecified, in ground".

Approximate value, calculated from TDS value in representative sample of mining effluent (dirty storage dam) multiplied by estimate of water loss through seepage (industry data). Most likely an overestimate as unspecified water outtputs are assumed to be seepage losses. Calculation also does not allow for attenuation in soils.

Calculated value, assuming unaccounted for water loss on the mines can be attributed to seepage to groundwater. Share of water loss to seepage is taken from Pulles et al. (2001), where a sample of 8 mines without coal preparation plants found that 41% of water is unaccounted for.Total water use by underground mines is assumed to be 215 litres/tonne ROM, The total water use value is derived from Pulles et al. (2001) and consultation with industry experts. Water figures are adjusted to exclude water for human consumption.References: Pulles, W., Boer, R. & Nel, S. 2001. A Generic Water Balance for the South African Coal Mining Industry. Water Research Commission Report No. 801/1/01.; Johan de Korte, Senior Researcher, Council for Scientific and Industrial Research (CSIR), telephonic interview, 7 June 2017.

Approximate value, calculated from concentration in representative sample of surface run-off (clean drains)  multiplied by estimate of water discharged to rivers (industry data). Possibly an underestimate as assumes only relatively clean water is discharged (effluent quality varies considerably between mines).

Most likely an overestimate as unspecified water outtputs are assumed to be seepage losses. Calculation also does not allow for attenuation in soils.

Research Commission Report No. 801/1/01.; Johan de Korte, Senior Researcher, Council for Scientific and Industrial Research (CSIR), telephonic interview, 7 June 2017.

exchanges.description:
EcoSpold01Location=GLO
Estimated value not geography specific (generic value used in other ecoinvent coal mining datasets). In this dataset infrastructure requirements are applied to total production over the life time. For this, the total production has to be estimated. A total production over life time of 3*10^10 kg is assumed (a nominal 30 years mine life at 1 mtpa is deemed a reasonable average for a South African coal mine).

exchanges.description: Approximate value, calculated from TDS value in representative sample of surface run-off (clean drains)  multiplied by estimate of water discharged to rivers (industry data). Possibly an underestimate as assumes only relatively clean water is discharged (effluent quality varies considerably between mines).

Average share of water use in underground mines filled by groundwater taken from Pulles et al. (2001), in which a sample of 16 underground mines found that groundwater accounted for 67% of water consumption. It should be noted however that groundwater use is very variable across the mines (ranging from 127 to 7 870 cubic metres/day). Thus goundwater use often depends more on whether the mine has a water ingress issue than whether the mine requires the water (i.e. water seeping into mine workings is a disposal issue rather than a water requirement). Total water use by underground mines is assumed to be 215 litres/tonne ROM, The total water use value is derived from Pulles et al. (2001) and consultation with industry. Water figures are adjusted to exclude water for human consumption.References: Pulles, W., Boer, R. & Nel, S. 2001. A Generic Water Balance for the South African Coal Mining Industry. Water 
Research Commission Report No. 801/1/01.; Johan de Korte, Senior Researcher, Council for Scientific and Industrial Research (CSIR), telephonic interview, 7 June 2017.

Generic estimate for underground mine, not specific to South Africa.

Comment from previous ecoinvent dataset: Regarding particulates, only those are considered which are not emitted during the combustion process and which are not deposited within the mining area. In AP 42 information about situational particle emission calculations and characteristical particle size distribution are given. 90 % of dust particles show sizes between 15 and 30 um, 10 % of dust particles are smaller than 15 um, 6 % of dust particles are smaller than 10 um and between 0.2 % und 1 % are smaller than 2.54 um. Regarding underground mining marginal emissions due to ventilation and slightly more emissions due to coal handling and the actual treatment step are estimated. Regarding opencast mining sharply increased emissions due to huge mining machines, lorries and open pits are estimated. Furthermore, emissions depend on climatic conditions (wind, precipitation, temperature) and the characteristics of coal (water content). In the literature figures regarding particle emissions range from 22 to 75 g/t. In this dataset particle emissions of 36 g/t are considered.

In various literature sources no information about other emissions emitted during underground mining are given respectively insignificant amounts are assumed, even though backfill processes show high specific emissions. 

In this dataset the following particle emissions factors are estimated: 

Particle emissions underground mining incl. treatment: 0.1 kg/t useable output

Particle emissions opencast mining incl. treatment: 0.4 kg/t useable output.

All emissions are assumed to be fly ash coarse particles (i.e. > 10 um).

Further references:

U.S. Departement of Energy (DOE) (1983) Energy Technonolgy Characterizations Handbook; Environmental Pollution and Control Factors. Washington, D.C.

ORNL (1980) A Methodology and a Preliminary Data Base for Examining the Health Risks of Electricity Generation from Uranium and Coal Fuels. Oak Ridge, USA.

Rentz O. (1991) Coal Use and Air Pollution Issues. In: Proceedings Coal in the Environment. London.

flow.name: Particulate Matter, > 10 um
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/low population density

exchanges.description: Total land transformed for mineral extraction activities at three underground coal mines in South Africa. Total land altered by the underground mines ranges from 900 - 2,800 hectares. As the mines in the sample are relatively mature, no further land is anticipated to be altered for extraction, thus the total land transformed is calculated as the total hectares altered divided by the estimated total coal production over the life of the mine (assuming constant coal production over a 30 year mine life). The mines report "Land altered for mineral extraction activities", so no differentiation is possible between operational areas and extraction areas. The value is however adjusted for disposal areas, which account for very little (less than 1.5%) in the mine without coal washing, and around 15% for the mines with washing plants. The discard disposal area is included in the coal preparation datasets. However, coal preparation area was not able to be differentiated, and is thus included in this dataset and not the coal preparation dataset.

Approximate value, calculated from concentration in representative sample of surface run-off (clean drains)  multiplied by estimate of water discharged to rivers (industry data). Possibly an underestimate as assumes only relatively clean water is discharged (effluent quality varies considerably between mines).

Approximate value, calculated from concentration in representative sample of surface run-off (clean drains)  multiplied by estimate of water discharged to rivers (industry data). Possibly an underestimate as assumes only relatively clean water is discharged (effluent quality varies considerably between mines).

Approximate value, calculated from concentration in representative sample of surface run-off (clean drains)  multiplied by estimate of water discharged to rivers (industry data). Possibly an underestimate as assumes only relatively clean water is discharged (effluent quality varies considerably between mines).

Generic estimate for coal, not specific to underground mining or to South Africa. 

Comment from previous ecoinvent dataset:Regarding radon emissions extensive measurements were taken to develop a measurement methodology and to review operating conditions. (Müller et al. 1992) 

Radon concentrations in air flow when leaving the shaft installations are most important to estimate specific radon emissions. Immission measurements at different measuring points (also badly aerated sites) show figures between 80 and 500 Bq/m3 (i.e. mean value of 200 Bq/m3). It was not possible to allocate specific air flow amounts per t extracted coal. According to about 20 % of the radon concentration of coal plus twice the concentration are emitted via overburden, which corresponds to 12 Bq/kg coal. (UNSCEAR 1988) No differentiation between opencast and underground mines has been made due to the lack of data. This figure is used in this dataset. 

Further references:

Müller W.-U., Streffer C., Schabronath J. (1992) Die Radonexposition im Steinkohlenbergbau des Ruhrgebietes. In: Reiners Ch., Streffer C., Messerschmidt O., Strahlenrisiko durch Radon. 32. Jahrestagung der Vereinigung Deutscher Strahlenschutzärzte e.V. in Essen 30. Mai - 1. Juni 1991, Stuttgart.

exchanges.description: Calculated value, assuming 2% of water output is as a result of discharge to surface water bodies. Share of water loss to surface discharge is taken from Pulles et al. (2001) (average value from a sample of  8 mines without coal preparation plants).Total water use by underground mines is assumed to be 215 litres/tonne ROM, The total water use value is derived from Pulles et al. (2001) and consultation with industry experts. Water figures are adjusted to exclude water for human consumption.References: Pulles, W., Boer, R. & Nel, S. 2001. A Generic Water Balance for the South African Coal Mining Industry. Water Research Commission Report No. 801/1/01.; Johan de Korte, Senior Researcher, Council for Scientific and Industrial Research (CSIR), telephonic interview, 7 June 2017.

Approximate value, calculated from concentration in representative sample of mining effluent (dirty storage dam) multiplied by estimate of water loss through seepage (industry data). Most likely an overestimate as unspecified water outtputs are assumed to be seepage losses. Calculation also does not allow for attenuation in soils.

Calculated from total land transformed for mineral extraction activities at three underground coal mines in South Africa. Total land altered by the underground mines ranges from 900 - 2,800 hectares. As the mines in the sample are relatively mature, no further land is anticipated to be altered for extraction, thus the total land transformed is calculated as the total hectares altered divided by the estimated total coal production over the life of the mine (assuming constant coal production over a 30 year mine life). Total land occupation over the life of the mine is calculated as land transformed multiplied by the years of operations (assumed to be 30) and time for revegetation (assumed to be 10 years). A relatively short time to rehabilitation is applied as, unlike in the past, legislation requires planning for closure at the start of the mine's operation.The mines report "Land altered for mineral extraction activities", so no differentiation is possible between operational areas and extraction areas. The value is however adjusted for disposal areas, which account for very little (less than 1.5%) in the mine without coal washing, and around 15% for the mines with washing plants. The discard disposal area is included in the coal preparation datasets. However, coal preparation area was not able to be differentiated, and thus is included in this dataset and not in the coal preparation dataset.

Average diesel use in three South African underground coal mines over two years of operation (industry data). Diesel is converted from litres to energy (MJ) using a density of 0.84 kg/litre and a calorific value of 42.7 MJ/kg. All diesel is assumed to be used in mining machinery. The relatively small amount of petrol use (0.02 litres/tonne) is not included in the dataset.
EcoSpold01Location=GLO

exchanges.description: This dataset represents run-of-mine coal, which is assumed to equate to coal extracted, "coal, hard, unspecified, in ground".

Approximate value, calculated from concentration in representative sample of mining effluent (dirty storage dam) multiplied by estimate of water loss through seepage (industry data). Most likely an overestimate as unspecified water outtputs are assumed to be seepage losses. Calculation also does not allow for attenuation in soils.

Approximate value, calculated from concentration in representative sample of surface run-off (clean drains)  multiplied by estimate of water discharged to rivers (industry data). Possibly an underestimate as assumes only relatively clean water is discharged (effluent quality varies considerably between mines).

Calculated from total land transformed for mineral extraction activities at three underground coal mines in South Africa (industry data). Total land altered by the underground mines ranges from 900 - 2,800 Hectares. As the mines in the sample are relatively mature, no further land is anticipated to be altered for extraction, thus the total land transformed is calculated as the total hectares altered divided by the estimated total coal production over the life of the mine (assuming constant coal production over a 30 year mine life). Coal mines fall predominantly in the grasslands regions of South Africa, thus this is chosen as the default. The mines report "Land altered for mineral extraction activities", so no differentiation is possible between operational areas and extraction areas. The total land area is however adjusted for disposal areas, which account for very little (less than 1.5%) in the mine without coal washing, and around 15% for the mines with washing plants. The discard disposal area is included in the coal preparation datasets. However, coal preparation area was not able to be differentiated, and is thus included in this dataset and not the coal preparation datasets.

flow.name: Transformation, from grassland, natural, for livestock grazing

exchanges.description:
Data on methane emissions from coal mining and handling are generally high in uncertainty because these emissions are hard to measure or estimate. However, their importance in terms of environmental impact is potentially considerable in some regions. South African coal is generally very low in methane emissions.
This emission factor is taken from South Africa's National GHG Inventory (0.77 m3/tonne). It aligns with data from four underground mines, with annual average methane emissions of 0.97 m3/tonne. A 2005 study by Llyod and Cook which estimates CH4 emissions from underground coal mines in South Africa at about 69.4 Gg per year. Applied to the production volume of this dataset, this results in specific emissions of 5.55E-04 kg CH4/kg coal, verifying the value in this dataset. No methane is captured or flared. Reference(s):  Department of Environmental Affairs (2014) GHG NATIONAL INVENTORY REPORT SOUTH AFRICA 2000 -2010, November 2014. <http://unfccc.int/resource/docs/natc/zafnir1.pdf>
Lloyd, P.J.D., Cook, A., 2005, Methane release from South African coalmines, The journal of The South African Institute of Mining and Metallurgy, volume 105, August 2005. <https://www.saimm.co.za/Journal/v105n07p483.pdf>, accessed July 2018
